sn45.11:4.2: “Mendicants, I wish to go on retreat for a fortnight.
sn45.11:4.3: No-one should approach me, except for the one who brings my alms-food.”
sn45.11:4.4: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. And no-one approached him, except for the one who brought the alms-food.
sn45.11:5.1: Then after a fortnight had passed, the Buddha came out of retreat and addressed the mendicants:
sn45.11:5.2: “Mendicants, I’ve been practicing part of the meditation I practiced when I was first awakened.
sn45.11:5.4: there’s feeling conditioned by wrong view
sn45.11:5.5: and feeling conditioned by right view. …
sn45.11:5.6: There’s feeling conditioned by wrong samādhi,
sn45.11:5.7: and feeling conditioned by right samādhi.
sn45.11:5.11: As long as desire, thought, and perception are not stilled, there is feeling conditioned by that.
sn45.11:5.12: When desire, thought, and perception are stilled, there is feeling conditioned by that.
sn45.11:5.13: There is effort to attain the unattained. As long as that state has not been attained, there is feeling conditioned by that.”
